title: Music festivals keep getting canned. Nearly half of Aussies say this could fix it
text:
Exclusive: Thousands of Australians have been directly affected by the slew of music festival cancellations over the last 12 months, including Park Waves festival this week.

Now they're calling for more government investment in the scene, according to a nine.com.au reader poll.

More than 40 per cent of﻿ the ﻿434 readers surveyed agreed that federal and state governments should invest in Australia's live music industry to support festivals and prevent more cancellations in 2026.

"The government should support music the same way they support international sports such as tennis, golf and soccer," one told 9news.com.au.﻿

A further 39 per cent of readers confessed to being at least 'somewhat concerned' about the future of Australian music festivals in light of recent events.

Park Waves festival, scheduled for February 2026, was cancelled on Tuesday due to challenges including economic issues.

"Ultimately, the numbers no longer stack up," organisers said in a statement.

Changing Tides 2025 was canned, and Groovin' The Moo cancelled its 2024 shows and didn't return in 2025.

Falls Festival and Splendour in the Grass gave 2025 a miss as well.

Long-running festival Splendour in the Grass did not return in 2025. (Mark Metcalfe/Stringer/Getty)

Money is the biggest issue for most Australian music festivals, according to two Creative Australia reports on the sector.

Rising operational costs, a lack of available funding and grants, and insurance costs have made it challenging for organisers to finance festivals.

Australians' ticket buying habits have also changed, creating uncertainty for organisers.

Festival goers ages 18 to 24 are purchasing tickets at lower rates﻿ than pre-pandemic.

Patterns of later ticket buying are also continuing, creating additional costs and risks some organisers simply can't keep up with.

G﻿roovin' the Moo cancelled its 2024 shows and didn't return in 2025. (Instagram/Groovin the Moo)

But when organisers have to jack up ticket prices to cope with ﻿rising operational costs, it prices some Aussies out altogether.

"Music festival tickets are too expensive," one reader said.

Another added that it's not surprising that Aussies can't afford them when many struggle to afford groceries and rent.

A combined 61 per cent of nine.com.au readers said they were ﻿'not very concerned' or 'not concerned at all' about festival cancellations.

But only 30 per cent were opposed to government investment in Australia's live music industry to support festivals.

One reader said events like festivals need to be self-sustainable, rather than relying on government support.

About 28 per cent of readers were on the fence about government investment.

"I don't go to music festivals but some could bring more tourism to the country so perhaps the government should invest in some," one said.

Others were concerned about how it could affect taxpayers.﻿

"Festivals should be supported by the music labels to support our music industry, not be taxpayer-funded," said one.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Aussies paying more for private health insurance and getting less
text:
Australians are paying more for private health insurance and getting less for their money in return, a new report from the country's top doctors' advocacy group says.

The Australian Medical Association has released its latest Private Health Insurance Report Card, which found that consumers were abandoning gold-tier policies and questioning the value of other policies, while insurer profits piled up ever higher.

The AMA said the sector was in urgent need of reform, and President Dr Danielle McMullen renewed the call to establish an independent private health authority to drive that process.

People are paying more for private health insurance and receiving less, a new report says. (Getty)

"Australia's health system is valued for its mix of public and private healthcare, but both parts of the system are under increasing pressure," McMullen said.

"Public hospitals are struggling with a severe logjam crisis, which is pushing more patients towards the private sector.

"However, runaway insurance premiums, low value offerings and shady tactics like product phoenixing leave customers facing tough choices about the level of cover they can afford."

Cost of living pressures are seeing people drop gold-tier policies. (Nine)

Australians are paying more for private health insurance and getting less for their money in return, a new report from the country's top doctors' advocacy group says. (Getty)

The report card showed that every year since 2008, the growth of private health insurance premiums has outstripped inflation, health sector inflation, average weekly earnings and the indexation of the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS).

Between 2008 and 2024, premiums climbed more than 100 per cent, while MBS indexation – which was frozen for several years from 2013 – increased by less than 20 per cent.

The report card also shows that over the six years to June 2025, insurers increased benefits paid for in-hospital medical treatment by only 18.1 per cent, while sector profits grew by nearly 50 per cent over the same period.

READ MORE: Manhunt for prisoner who escaped from police at hospital ﻿

In 2024-2025, insurers returned 84.2 per cent of premiums to consumers as benefits, below the 2019 level of 88 per cent.

The AMA is calling on the federal government to mandate a 90 per cent return minimum for insurers.

"Of course, private health insurers must make a surplus to be sustainable, but it is clear they are holding out on Australians while recording significant profits each year," McMullen said.

The AMA is calling for major reform. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"These insurers have ample capacity to increase the benefits paid to patients."

The report also found gold-tier policies are in decline as consumers face rising premiums and cost-of-living pressures.

Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020, the number of gold-tier policies have dropped by 360,000, despite the overall number of policies growing.

"These trends show that private health insurance is becoming less affordable for many Australians – and we are already seeing the drastic effects of this, with at least 14 private maternity units closing over the past five years," McMullen said.

"The need for a Private Health System Authority to better regulate the sector and drive long-term reform has never been more crucial. There are too many bodies involved in the regulation of private health – a single, independent authority would provide a unified and coherent approach."

title: Thailand eases alcohol ban to attract more tourists
text:
Thailand has temporarily eased a ban on the sale of afternoon alcoholic drinks in a move aimed to attract more tourists.

Restaurants, bottle shops and other authorised outlets can now sell beer, wine and spirits from 2pm to 5pm as part of a six-month trial, the BBC reports.

Overseas tourists, including Australians, have often been confused by the afternoon prohibition of alcohol sales ﻿in Thailand, a top destination for partygoers.

Tourists in Thailand will find buying an afternoon alcoholic drink easier after authorities eased a decades-old ban. (AP Photo/Sa (AP)

It was started in 1972, partly to deter public servants from drinking during work hours.

Alcohol sales in Thailand are now permitted from 11am to midnight during the next 180 days while an expert panel examines its impact.

Previously, breaking the ban carried the risk of a fine up to 10,000 baht﻿ ($437).

The change comes in the lead-up to the Christmas and the New Year holiday, both peak periods for tourists.﻿

New Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul has pledged to kickstart the economy by reviving tourism following years of political unrest.

Local beer brands Chang and Singha are favourites among overseas visitors,﻿

About 800,000 Australians visit Thailand every year, according to Tourism Research Australia.﻿

title: Experts caution against taking medical advice from influencers
text:
Experts have called for greater governance on potentially misleading medical advice shared by influencers on social media.

Whilst over 40 per cent of young adults in the USA take advice from influencers, a report in The BMJ claims people are at risk of getting incorrect or biased information on important medical issues.

For example, Kim Kardashian encouraged her 360 million followers to have a full-body screening with magnetic resonance imaging.

READ MORE: ﻿ Scorching heatwave to smother major city as hot air mass moves across state

Kim Kardashian has previously promoted medical treaments with no proven benefits. (Getty)

While scans can have a benefit for people at a high-risk of certain conditions it is also linked to overdiagnosis and unnecessary medical interventions.

The fourth overlapping biases, according to the authors, include "limited expertise, industry influence, entrepreneurial interests, and personal belief.

"Such advice can cause psychological, physical, financial, and systemic harm," the report continued.

The report says influencers create a tight bond and relationship with their followers, with the sharing of real-life experiences helping foster a connection.

They can also help break stigmas surrounding certain medical conditions.

Lily Mae, also known as @chronicallylil on Instagram, documents her journey in navigating multiple medical conditions. (Instagram/@chronicallylil)

However, the report argues more government oversight is required to ensure influencers do not mislead their followers or promote unethical practices.

Australia already has some laws and regulations in place, banning paid health testimonials.

Some influencers believe medical experts should work more closely with them, believing they can bridge a key gap.

"I wish healthcare professionals would listen and engage more with patient communities online," Lily Mae, whose Instagram account @chronicallylil shows her struggles with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, endometriosis, and vascular compression syndrome.

"There's such a wealth of firsthand knowledge being shared—real stories, symptoms, and lived experiences that could help improve care if more providers took the time to understand them."

title: Ayers Rock Resort operation being sold to US company
text:
The Ayers Rock Resort at Uluru is set to change hands, after the Indigenous Land and Sea Corporation (ILSC) came to an agreement with "experiential tourism" company Journey Beyond.

Journey Beyond is owned by American private equity firm Crestview Partners and already operates several high-profile tourism assets, including the Ghan and Indian Pacific railways.

The deal sees Journey Beyond purchase the operational assets of ILSC subsidiary Voyages Indigenous Tourism Australia, which include the Ayers Rock Resort and the Mossman Gorge Cultural in Far North Queensland.

Land and buildings at both locations will be transferred to traditional owners, Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara of Yulara and the Kuku Yalanji of Mossman Gorge.

Valuation review questions Ayers Rock Resort buy An advisory group that delivered the highest valuation for central Australia's Ayers Rock Resort in 2010 was paid a fee based on the purchase price.

The move brings to an end a 15-year foray into large tourism ventures by the ILSC.

In 2010, the Indigenous Land Corporation board announced with great fanfare that it was buying the Ayers Rock Resort, near Uluru, for $300 million.

The deal with Journey Beyond is likely to be for less than $300 million and, while Voyages Indigenous Tourism was never supposed to be just about making a profit, the impending sale has some people asking questions, like was it worth it?

What is the Indigenous Land and Sea Corporation?

The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC), now known as the Indigenous Land and Sea Corporation (ILSC), was set up in 1995 in the wake of the historic Mabo High Court decision that recognised Torres Strait Islander and Aboriginal traditional title to land.

One of the ILC's functions is to manage the Land Account, which aims to help Indigenous people to acquire land and manage it in a sustainable way, to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for themselves and future generations.

The direction and responsibilities of the ILSC have evolved over the years and now include a wide range of Indigenous-led projects, agribusinesses, tourism enterprises and to help native title holders, if needed.

The ILSC board is the primary decision-making body and oversees governance, considers land acquisition and land management proposals and monitors performance.

The board consists of seven directors appointed by the federal minister for Indigenous Australians. Five of them, including the chairperson, must be Indigenous people.

Why did the board buy Ayers Rock Resort?

In 2007, the ILC decided to focus on education, training and employment.

This meant a considerable expansion to build businesses and create training opportunities.

The ILC announced it had acquired Ayers Rock Resort at Yulara near Uluru from property giant GPT for $300 million in October 2010.

Resort between Rock and hard place after shake-up The former board chairman of Voyages Indigenous Tourism Australia calls for federal government action on the Ayers Rock Resort in the Northern Territory.

"The resort represents a unique and probably the biggest opportunity to advance the training and employment of Indigenous people in the Australian tourism and hospitality industries," ILC chairperson Shirley McPherson said at the time.

The idea was to increase Indigenous employment at the resort from a handful to more than half the staff members and to establish a National Indigenous Tourism Training Academy, with 200 people in training each year from 2013.

Was the purchase contentious?

When she was appointed ILC chair in 2011, Dr Dawn Casey started digging into the purchase.

And she was outraged by what she found.

Property giant GPT originally offered the resort to the ILC for $270 million in 2009, but the sale price was revised upwards by $30 million in 2010.

In a 2015 letter to then-prime minister Tony Abbott, Dr Casey alleged the former ILC board agreed to the increased price "without any sound reasoning documented in the [then ILC board] minutes".

Allegations $30m missing in Uluru resort deal Taxpayers "inexplicably" paid an "unjustified" $30 million in a deal to buy Ayers Rock Resort in 2010, a letter to the prime minister alleges.

The letter states:

"[This was] despite strong concerns from certain directors and due diligence advisers indicating that the purchase price may not have been commensurate with the resort's value."

Banks had refused to finance the full acquisition in 2009, and then-indigenous affairs minister Jenny Macklin declined to back the purchase and forbade access to the Land Account for it.

When GPT increased the resort's sale price in 2010, the property giant proposed a new seller-financed model, also called vendor finance, where the seller loans the purchaser all or part of a loan that they would not otherwise be able to secure.

That meant the ILC was able to borrow $198 million to buy the resort, including land, buildings, infrastructure and the nearby airport at Yulara.

In 2016, then-Indigenous affairs minister Nigel Scullion authorised a $65 million federal government bailout for the ILC to help refinance the resort, blaming the global financial crisis.

Voyages still has an external debt of more that $100 million.

What is the resort worth?

While Uluru has been a sacred and spiritual place for Aboriginal peoples for thousands of years, tourists have been flocking to the rock since the first graded road from Alice Springs was completed in the 1950s.

By 1968, visitor numbers had grown to more than 20,000 annually but facilities at the base of Uluru were unregulated, driving governments to develop the concept of a resort during the 1970s.

The original tourism site is now the Indigenous township of Mutitjulu.

The resort was opened in 1984 and celebrated its 40th anniversary last year.

Loading Instagram content

It is the only place tourists can stay to visit Uluru and contains a range of accommodation options from campsites through to high-end rooms, restaurants, pools and an art gallery.

But by the time the ILC took possession of the resort in early 2011, it needed renovating and modernising.

In October 2013, the ILC announced it had written $62 million off the value of the resort.

It also said it was having trouble dealing with its annual interest repayments of about $10 million.

In January 2014, the resort was revalued again down to $202.5 million.

And, like all tourism ventures, it was adversely affected by the pandemic from 2020.

The Ayers Rock Resort welcomes tens of thousands of domestic and international tourists each year. (Supplied)

Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Kerrynne Liddle, an Arrernte woman, worked for Voyages Tourism for a few years, to increase Indigenous employment outcomes and help the resort better engage with the local Mutitjulu community.

She said it was a worthwhile and valuable exercise that involved a lot of resetting relationships with the local community.

"My focus was also making sure that Aboriginal people weren't only employed at the lower levels of the business, that they could do anything," she said.

Senator Liddle said, in her time at the resort, Indigenous people were able to access registered training, and were employed in all sorts of roles, from front of house to senior leadership.

"People came from all over Australia to work there and … it's pretty special when you walk into a hotel anywhere in Australia and see Indigenous people just doing their jobs … it is really wonderful to see," she said.

Ayers Rock Resort is the only place tourists can stay when visiting Uluru. (Supplied)

But, despite the positive outcomes in training and employment, Senator Liddle has questions.

"Unfortunately, it struggled to operate effectively from a profit perspective because of the extraordinary way in which it was financed," she said.

" We may effectively have a business that's operated for many years … and you have to ask the question was this such a great investment to begin with? "

Looking back, Dr Casey says there's "no doubt" that the training and employment programs were valuable and excellent.

"But it did hamstring us in terms of the funding that we had to pay out on loans," she said.

"We set it up so that we could see exactly how much it cost to operate, separated it out from the rest of the budget and, yeah, it was a major concern for during the period that we were there."

What's for sale?

Voyages' operational assets are being sold to Journey Beyond.

The land will be divested to the traditional owners at both Yulara and Mossman Gorge, with the ILSC saying there has been multi-year consultation and engagement with Anangu in Central Australia and the Kuku Yalanji in Far North Queensland.

Later, following the transfer of land to community corporations, both communities will be paid rent from Journey Beyond's leasing of the sites under 90 and 10-year leases, respectively.

The sale has already been brought to the attention of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

Land at Mossman Gorge will be handed back to Kuku Yalanji people. (Supplied: Tourism and Events Queensland)

In addition, in central Australia there are to be areas that will remain outside of a leasing arrangement and remain with community.

One of those areas will be used to develop a business hub, for Anangu (local people) and there is another area which is being set aside, outside of the lease, where Anangu can look to develop their own cultural tourism activities, not just rely on a partnership with Voyages to run experiences at the resort.

In a statement, Yulara Aboriginal Corporation said they were happy with the decision to hand back land that was originally excised from Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park and looking forward to working with Journey Beyond "in the development of world class Indigenous tourism experiences that will share our language, our culture and our rich landscapes with visitors".

The transaction is expected to be finalised in early 2026, along with the divestment of the Yulara land to Anangu.

The Mossman Gorge land divestment will follow once the native title application that embraces the cultural centre site is determined.

title: 'Go out for dinner': Free fares for summer amid Canberra construction chaos
text:
The ACT government has announced changes to the public transport network as major construction continues on Commonwealth Avenue Bridge.

From February, Canberra's bus timetable will be altered to allow for the project, which is being delivered by the National Capital Authority and is expected to take two years.

The changes include reduced frequency for some rapid bus services.

ACT Transport Minister Chris Steel also announced today that a free public transport initiative would run over the summer to support the night-time economy in Civic amid construction on light rail stage 2A.

And from next week, it will be free to use bus and light rail services from 6pm on Fridays and Saturdays until the end of February.

Commonwealth Avenue Bridge is an important link between Canberra's north and south. (ABC News: Joel Wilson)

That free travel coincides with the end of a year-long trial of fare-free Fridays in Canberra.

The government said it was not until February that the full impact of the bridge renewal project would be felt, when term 1 of school commenced.

The government urged Canberrans to travel outside peak times when possible.

ACT Transport Minister Chris Steel urged Canberrans to "go out for dinner or a drink" over summer. (Facebook: Chris Steel MLA)

"The updated bus network is based on traffic modelling which tells us that the southbound morning peak travel across Commonwealth Avenue will be most impacted by the construction works," a government statement said.

"Travel times are expected to increase by around 13 minutes southbound on Commonwealth Avenue. This reduces to around an additional seven minutes by the afternoon peak.

"The project will also have flow on impacts on major roads and the broader traffic network including Kings Avenue. The impacts are projected to be significant and we encourage the community to plan ahead before you travel whether by bus or by private vehicle."

The $137.5 million project includes strengthening the bridge, widening its shared pathways, installing new lighting, and replacing safety barriers.

At its peak, it means only one side of the bridge will be open at a time, seeing its six lanes shrink to three to accommodate traffic, pedestrians and cyclists travelling in both directions.

Changes to bus network beginning February

Changes to Canberra's bus network will begin on February 2, including the introduction of a dedicated bus and emergency services priority lane northbound across Commonwealth Avenue Bridge.

The rapid bus service standard weekday frequency will be 15 minutes across the network until 7:30pm.

Rapid bus services set to be reduced in frequency include services 2, 3, and 4, which operate in the Belconnen area.

But other rapid bus services will be changed in a bid to ease the reduction in those services.

A new bus timetable will be released in January detailing the alterations. (ABC News: Callum Flinn)

Buses to Marcus Clarke Street will also change.

The government said dedicated school services would remain the same as in the current bus network, "with temporary adjustment including timing for 51 schools".

The light rail line will be unaffected.

Timetables will be released in January, the government said.

Transport Canberra executive group manager Jeremy Smith said the changes were necessary to "ensure that Transport Canberra resources are used in the most effective way possible".

"While changes may mean adjusted travel times or altered routes for some passengers, bus services will be monitored, reviewed and refined to align with demand, impact and operational conditions," Mr Smith said.

Fare-free weekend evenings amid light rail construction

Only one side of Commonwealth Avenue Bridge will be open at a time at the peak of the works. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

Transport Minister Chris Steel said the modified public transport network was necessary as the work continued.

"I acknowledge that it is going to be incredibly disruptive for Canberrans while the federal government's bridge works are underway," Mr Steel said.

"We have worked hard to make sure we deliver a reliable bus network during the construction period, with capacity to move as many Canberrans as possible.

"I am committed to revising the bus timetable once the community has had some time to adjust to the new traffic environment and we understand what the actual impacts are on travel times."

Parts of London Circuit in Canberra have been closed for construction work of light rail stage 2A. (ABC News: Joel Wilson)

Mr Steel encouraged Canberrans to visit the CBD over summer, which is also experiencing disruptions as construction work as part of light rail stage 2A continues.

Businesses in the area say they have been negatively impacted due to road closures and reduced foot traffic.

"The new free night-time travel trial is intended to encourage Canberrans to get out and support our great food and entertainment businesses across the city," Mr Steel said.

"Go out for dinner or a drink over the summer and you can enjoy a free ride home on a bus or light rail."

title: Reclusive millionaire builds massive gold stockpiles amid record prices
text:
A prospector who amassed a fortune in Western Australia's mining industry after pegging ground covering some of Kalgoorlie's richest gold mines has no plans to sell large stockpiles of the metal being stored at the Perth Mint.

Anton Billis, also known as Anthony, is a one-time bankrupt who remains a reclusive enigma in the resources sector.

The 81-year-old is managing director of ASX-listed gold miners Tribune Resources and Rand Mining, which own a combined 49 per cent stake in the rich East Kundana joint venture.

The Croatian-born prospector's combined shareholding in Tribune and Rand was this week worth about $141 million.

Since 2005, the companies' combined share of production from Kalgoorlie mines such as Raleigh, Rubicon-Hornet and Pegasus has topped 1.33 million ounces — a big chunk of which has been stockpiled at the mint.

Precious metals worth billions of dollars are stored at the Perth Mint. (Supplied: Perth Mint)

Magical run for gold price

Stock market filings show Tribune had gold on its books valued at $177.01 million at June 30, while Rand's holdings were worth $70.08 million.

Mr Billis said he had no plans to sell the gold holdings other than to meet financial commitments and provide sufficient working capital.

"We use that to pay cash calls and to pay for dividends, the rest of it stays in the Perth Mint," he said.

"Everyone thought I was a bit eccentric. I think that gold will continue to go up higher.

" Gold is a currency that won't rust, it will always appreciate. "

The Perth Mint sells stamped products all over the world. (Supplied: Perth Mint)

The appreciation in value of Tribune and Rand's stockpiles reflects this year's magical run for the gold price.

The metal surpassed $5,000 an ounce for the first time in April, and then hit $6,000 an ounce in October.

Billions deposited at Perth Mint

Australia produced 76 tonnes of gold in the September quarter, according to Melbourne-based gold consultancy Surbiton Associates, worth about $15.5 billion at current prices.

WA miners produce most of the country's gold and typically sell to the government-owned Perth Mint at the daily spot price.

The 126-year-old mint refines bars into 99.9 per cent bullion and sells stamped products like bars and coins around the world.

According to its annual report, the Perth Mint refined 225.4 tonnes of gold last financial year, while its depository held gold and other metals in secure vaults valued at $10.4 billion at June 30.

While Mr Billis's companies stand out, fellow ASX-listed miners Black Cat Syndicate and Beacon Minerals have also recently adopted policies of retaining a portion of production in gold bullion storage.

The Australian dollar gold price has hit record highs this year. (Supplied: Brightstar Resources)

No superstition on gold

Black Cat Syndicate restarted the Paulsens gold mine in WA's Pilbara last year, and more recently acquired the Lakewood mill near Kalgoorlie for $85 million to process gold from its Kal East project.

As of September 30, Black Cat had 5,104 ounces in storage, worth about $29.6 million.

The company estimates its gold has appreciated somewhere between $3 million and $4 million since adopting its strategy.

Black Cat managing director Gareth Solly (centre) with board members Les Davis and Davide Bosio at their Lakewood plant's first gold pour in April. (Supplied: ASX/Black Cat Syndicate)

"It is hard to justify producing a safe-haven asset in gold and then converting that into an asset losing its purchasing power in cash," managing director Gareth Solly told Black Cat's annual shareholder meeting on November 27.

"At the end of the day, we are in the gold business."

Gold bars from the Paulsens mine in the Pilbara. (Supplied: ASX/Black Cat Syndicate)

Black Cat chairman Paul Chapman also spoke at the AGM, pointing to a recent report by the World Gold Council which expects 95 per cent of central banks to increase their gold reserves over the next 12 months.

"Gold is no longer seen as an artefact, but a currency," he said.

Metal's 'strategic value'

Coolgardie gold miner Beacon Minerals held 4,615 ounces of gold at the Perth Mint at September 30 and reported another 1,393 ounces was in transit, with the combined value worth about $36.27 million.

Beacon's managing director, Graham McGarry, said the gold price reaching a record $6,448 an ounce on October 14 highlighted the strength of the market and the "strategic value" of retained gold holdings.

Beacon Minerals boss Graham McGarry at the company's Jaurdi gold project near Coolgardie. (ABC Goldfields: Jarrod Lucas)

"Our decision to hold gold in excess of that required to meet operational and capital commitments has delivered a tangible uplift to shareholder value," Mr McGarry said in Beacon's quarterly report.

"The board regularly reviews the company's policy of holding gold at the Perth Mint, and we currently see no reason to alter this strategy."

title: Behich, Socceroos eyeing rematch against World Cup giants
text:
Eagerly anticipating the World Cup draw, Aziz Behich can't help but dream of settling some unfinished business with Argentina.

In Qatar in 2022, Behich and Garang Kuol were denied late chances to equalise against eventual champions Argentina as the Socceroos' golden run ended in the round of 16.

In the draw for next year's global showpiece, to be held on Saturday at 4am (AEDT), Argentina will be in Pot 1 with the Socceroos in Pot 2, making for a one-in-12 shot at a group stage reunion.

"Look, that would be great if we get another shot at them," Behich told AAP.

"That's football — the game can turn so quick. And we had two opportunities to make that game something special.

"But that whole campaign was just special in general, the way we got out of the group there, and I'd love to be a part of something like that again.

Argentina beat Australia’s Socceroos 2-0 The irrepressible Lionel Messi again brings the Socceroos' undone, scoring the fastest goal of his international career as Argentina claims a friendly victory in Beijing.

"And why not take it one more step forward in a World Cup?"

Landing in Pot 2 should help Australia avoid any "group of death'' scenarios — but Behich doesn't care.

"I've really never believed in a group of death or anything like that because if a team's at the World Cup, they're there for a reason," he said.

"That means they're the best in their area and they qualified. Come the World Cup, they're one-off games, so for me, any game's a tough game.

"Anything's possible when it comes to football and it's proven week in, week out, not just at international level.

"We showed that in the last World Cup. No one gave us a chance in Qatar and we went out swinging against the champions of that World Cup — and we could have snagged something there in that game as well.

"So whatever group comes, it's a challenge — but if there's one thing that us Aussies pride ourselves on, it's performing with our backs against the wall against the best.

"So it's more of just excitement and a 'bring it on' type mentality."

Behich hopes an expanded 48-team tournament minimises the chance of a third consecutive World Cup group involving France and Denmark.

"It'd be nice, obviously, to get a different draw because the last two World Cups had a few of the same teams," he said.

Lionel Messi hoists the trophy after Argentina's win over France in the 2022 World Cup final. (Getty Images: Tom Jenkins)

There will clearly be far more travel than the 2022 Doha tournament, with games sprawled across Canada, the United States and Mexico — a challenge Behich welcomes.

Melbourne City skipper Behich, who missed the Socceroos' last window with a hamstring injury, is determined to reach a third World Cup, and compete with Jordy Bos for the starting left-back role.

"When it comes to the national team, there's always competition and it's healthy for the team," he said.

"So it's one thing I don't shy away from. I just believe in my own ability, what I'm capable of."

Behich won't watch the draw live, given it's game day for Melbourne City in Newcastle, but will catch up with it when he wakes up.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"I'll be straight on the TV to have a look at the draw, and it'll be exciting to see who our opponents will be for the first phase," he said.

"When the draw comes out, then the countdown begins.

"If you put all sports together, the World Cup is the pinnacle of everything.

"It's the biggest event in the world — pretty much the whole world's watching when it comes around.

"So hopefully I'm in good stead come selection time and I can go around one more time."

AAP

title: Australia's red-tipped bananas go viral after cheeky social media post
text:
Red-tipped bananas are not new to Australian consumers, but have gone viral on social media this month after an inquisitive post from two bewildered British backpackers.

The video from travellers Mel Chekaoui and Phil Colia has been seen more than 11 million times on Instagram, with eager consumers commenting that they too were hungry to learn the reason for the red wax tip.

Loading Instagram content

"My Dad told me it meant they were strawberry flavoured and I believed him until I was 16 years old. Nice to finally learn the real reason in the comments"

"Legit my favourite bananas, and I don't even know why"

"Baby-bel bananas"

"Christian Louboutin version of bananas"

Pioneered by Innisfail farmers Dianne and Frank Sciaccia in Far North Queensland, the red wax tip indicates bananas that have been grown using their Ecoganic farming method.

"Stores actually have a sign that says 'uniquely Ecoganic', but I mean [social media] is just the way the young ones communicate today," Ms Sciaccia said.

"[When I saw the video] I just laughed."

Ms Sciaccia said the accredited farming system used natural ecosystems to grow the crop and promote soil health, minimising other inputs such as chemical fertilisers and insecticides.

It is different to organic farming because not all products used are free of inputs.

The bananas are grown to a recognised standard in order to be accredited. (ABC Rural: Sophie Johnson)

While the red tips are more widely known to appear on bananas, producers of other crops have also started to adopt the farming method.

"We've had a lot of interest from different industries, so we've been working with avocadoes, apples and pears in Victoria, and almond growers in South Australia for the past couple of years," Ms Sciaccia said.

"We're just putting some focus back into papaya, which we did start a few years ago, but due to crop loss, we sort of put that on hold at the time."

Pawpaw potential

There are eight certified growers nationally, including William Darveniza.

His farm is up the road from the Sciaccia's, about 260 kilometres north of Townsville, and his range of crops includes the red-tipped bananas.

This is his first year formally producing the fruit, after he realised he had already been using the farming method.

William Darveniza farms multiple crops near Innisfail in Far North Queensland. (ABC Rural: Sophie Johnson)

He hopes to add the red tip to other fruits on the farm, including paw paws.

"A lot of those mycorrhizal fungi and the bacteria that they evolved alongside in the rainforest are sort of taken out of the equation in the conventional farming system that we have," said Mr Darveniza.

"I'd like to sort of try and reintroduce that a little bit and help protect the crop from these weather situations and these insect pressures using that system."

He hoped a wider range of red-tipped fruit would be on supermarket shelves by mid-next year.

"There has already been a fair bit of interest in the product, so we're looking forward to moving forward with it," he said.

Mr Darveniza is going to grow red-tipped pawpaws next year. (ABC Rural: Sophie Johnson)

Red-tipped exports

Across all growers, about 80 tonnes of red-tipped bananas are produced a week, and they are not only turning heads in Australia.

Ms Sciaccia said international interest had grown since they first sent trial volumes of bananas with the waxy, red tips to Japan about two years ago.

"We've been working with one of the major supermarkets over there and putting together a business plan with them," she said.

"They've done all of their testing on the product, and the texture, taste, what they call sensory attributes, sit above any other product that they import from around the world."

She was hopeful of sending commercial volumes to Japan in the future.

"I don't see the export as being a major part of our business, but it certainly has the potential to be as equal to our domestic market quite easily," Ms Sciaccia said.

title: Leaked texts from inside Australian billionaire's VIP gamblers club
text:
Messages between Australian multi-billionaire Ed Craven and a former associate reveal the inner workings of his online casino empire.

All it took was a splashy gambling spree for Chris to announce himself as a new high roller at Stake.

Over a few whirlwind months of gambling, the Swedish millionaire lost more than $US150,000 at the online casino.

In doing so, he gained something more valuable: a direct line to Stake's CEO and co-founder, Ed Craven.

Eddie: Sup Chris

Eddie: You were one of the top players on Stake in August

Eddie: Special bonus here - https://stake.com/?bonus=EddieTopAugustVIPs 🙂

Eddie: Hope you have a nice September dude

Stake was on the rise, soon to be a global gambling juggernaut, but its CEO still found the time to roll out the VIP treatment for its top clients.

A few months in, Chris offered up a tantalising clue about how profitable he could be for the casino.

Chris: i'm down like €2.3m on bitcasino

Eddie: Really, wow lol

The full transcript of their conversations between 2020 and 2024 — obtained exclusively by the ABC — shows Chris taking on many roles at Stake: client, collaborator, informant, and rule-breaker.

In the process, it offers a look inside how one of Australia's richest people built his gambling empire, and how he ignored numerous red flags suggesting his associate had a serious gambling problem.

In 2025, Chris commenced legal proceedings seeking to reclaim $US1.5 million of losses at Stake, using his conversations with the Stake CEO in support of a claim that the company had exploited his addiction.

Ed Craven declined to comment; Stake's head of PR, Audrey Fitzgerald, said the company would not comment on active litigation.

On the surface, much of the chat between the pair is light-hearted. Craven jokes about "sketchy" casinos, and games "designed to f*** player[s]". He advises Chris on his role as a promoter for the casino, shares screenshots of jackpots and resolves the occasional technical issue.

Chris: always good to be able to contact so fast not many have that :)

Eddie: No problem man, least can do

But underneath it all, colouring almost every interaction, were signs that his VIP client had a gambling problem.

Chris tells Craven about going "overboard on the live blackjack", suffering "bad losses", and makes quips about "losing track of money" when he's faced with the raw numbers. They also openly discuss several of Chris's attempts to have himself barred from gambling on Stake.

The messages also show Craven advising Chris not to circumvent a self-imposed ban in 2022. "I think it's kinda dumb too," wrote the Stake CEO, "but at the same time there's a lot of people it helps."

Chris did it anyway. And still, he says, Craven acted "as if nothing had changed". Chris continued to gamble at Stake — and chat with Craven about it — for another two years.

Chris's parents had no idea their 17-year-old son was a teenage millionaire in 2020, much less that he was at risk of gambling his fortune away.

From a young age, the Swedish teenager had discovered a knack for trading video game items online.

He converted his winnings into cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin and Ethereum, back when they were worth relatively little. By 2020, these coins had multiplied in value and Chris's crypto fortune had swelled into the millions.

Chris kept his online exploits to himself. His parents only caught rare glimpses of his new-found wealth, like when they helped him cash out a tiny portion of it to buy a new computer.

As he grew up, Chris found himself unable to resist playing the virtual slot machines at several online casinos. The teenager burned through massive amounts of crypto in a matter of months, much of it on a site called Bitcasino — one of the first online casinos to accept cryptocurrencies.

Online, Chris was more open about his gambling habit. He would post screenshots of the occasional jackpot on Twitter, interspersed with despairing comments about how much he was losing.

But this schtick was about more than just venting. By posting about special offers at Bitcasino, accessible through his personal referral code, Chris found another way to fund his gambling.

Anyone who used that code to sign up would be doing Chris a big favour.

Whenever these people — called his "affiliates" — spent money on Bitcasino, Chris would get a cut for referring them. It was a kind of gambling pyramid scheme, where influencers profited off the misfortune of their fans.

This Faustian bargain offered by online casinos had spawned an entire universe of gambling influencers, each jostling for a share in the bonanza of affiliate revenue.

This meant that, as Chris was growing his list of affiliates, he was simultaneously being courted by others trying to do the same. And it wasn't long before Stake, a relative newcomer to the online "crypto casino" space, started cannibalising the player bases of its more storied competitors.

Midway through 2020, with the pandemic trapping millions of gamblers in their homes, Craven saw an opportunity to reach a larger audience.

That was when he hired Akhil Sarin as Stake's first official marketer, a job that came with one massive hitch.

As Stake was licensed in Curaçao — a tax haven in the Caribbean with minimal oversight for casinos — it was banned in many popular gambling markets, including in Australia, the US and much of Europe. This meant that it couldn't be advertised through traditional means.

But Sarin soon had an idea he wanted to try out: partnering with people who would live-stream themselves as they gambled on their site. Craven wasn't initially sold on the idea, according to Sarin, but he allowed his new lieutenant to spend a month trying it out.

Akil Sarin (grey suit, white shirt) was hired by Ed Craven (light blue jeans) in 2020. ( )

Before long, tens of thousands of people were tuning in to watch their favourite streamers play Stake's virtual slot machines, clicking a button over and over again. A community of young gamblers materialised on Twitch, the world's most popular live streaming platform.

The Stake team were blown away by the success of their new marketing strategy. "I think the pivotal moment was the [rate of] conversion of viewers," Sarin later told an industry podcast. "Live-streaming is the absolute best way to market any product."

Stake used a similar incentive for its streamers as Chris had been offered by Bitcasino — they were entitled to a cut of each bet made by anyone they referred to the site, continuing into perpetuity.

Over time, Stake struck deals with online celebrities such as xQc and Trainwreck, both of whom signed contracts — reportedly worth more than $US1 million per month — that required them to gamble live for their fans.

Do you know more? Contact Julian Fell at tips@jtfell.com if you have any information about crypto casinos in Australia.

Chris switched over to Stake after being lured in with a sweetheart deal of his own. "They gave me a VIP deal there," Chris recalls, "because I was playing with a lot of money."

That meant the 17-year-old had a direct line to "Eddie" — the big boss, Ed Craven.

Their earliest interactions were playful. The two of them would banter about Chris's losses and discuss Stake's competitors.

At one point, Craven suggested that Chris's betting limit, already at an astronomical $US25,000 per hand of blackjack, could be raised even higher.

Chris: lost 110 [bitcoin] in like 2 hours becuase [Bitcasino] had stupid amounts as limits

Eddie: Damn

Eddie: On Blackjack?

Chris: yep, and baccarat

Chris: i did private baccarat and private [blackjack] tables

Eddie: Haha damn

Eddie: If you ever need Stake's limits increased let me know

Eddie: We can get up to $100k/hand

Eddie: But yeh I guess it's dangerous having that available 24/7 I can set it for like 1 hour or 2 hours for you if you like

Chris: 100k? haha might need it someday:)

Eddie: Easy, just one message away

During a discussion of Chris's "cash back" entitlements — a promotion where a portion of his gambling losses were periodically returned to him — Chris said he was thinking of sticking to slot games for the next little while.

Chris: wanted to try to stick to slots for a lil bit and see how it goes

Eddie: Hahaha, I recall that never working out too well for you 😂

Chris: Yup im the worst one when it comes to slots hehe

Eddie: Hahah, yeh live games more fun tbh

Eddie: Slots also real hard to profit

Eddie: Designed to f*** player

Chris: true gonna try another [deposit] tomorrow and see how it goes:)

Eddie: Hopefully a decent streak :)

The signs that Chris had a problem were never far from the surface.

Chris asked if it was "possible to disable evolution [games] specifically or is it still not possible? [Makes] me go crazy with the bad luck there". He complained about "bad losses" on the slots and blackjack, and often voiced frustration about his inability to stick to sports betting.

Stake's own website acknowledges the devastating impact problem gambling can have. "Although problem gambling often results in financial problems," it says, "the impact of problem gambling usually stretches much further than this."

In between these dire interactions, Craven continued giving Chris inducements, including a percentage of cash back on his losses, and helped him to claim the income he was owed through referring other players.

Chris: Hey could you check for some cashback had a nother loss. maybe some extra available on top? :D

Chris: bit of a bad luck streak again

Eddie: Hey man I got you 😄

Eddie: All set in vault

In late 2021, Chris got his account permanently banned via a process called self-exclusion. This is a tool offered to players who have identified that they have a gambling problem, so they can avoid relapsing.

He told Craven it was an accident and later asked to have his VIP perks transferred over to a new account so he could keep gambling on Stake. "Umm not the best idea to try get around the exclusion man," replied Craven.

A few weeks later, Chris asked to apply some perks to an account of a "buddy". "All set 🙂," Stake's co-founder replied.

The charade about it being a friend's account was quickly dropped, and their interactions fell back into their usual rhythm — Chris repeatedly asking to have a percentage of his losses refunded, Craven offering words of encouragement and incentives to keep playing.

Chris's earlier, supposedly permanent, self-exclusion was seemingly lost to time.

In all, he created seven different accounts across on Stake. "Whenever I made a new account, I would just message," he says. "I would just give [Craven] the name and say, 'This is my new account.'"

Chris's gambling only represented a tiny slice of the money being poured into Craven's burgeoning online empire.

Stake's popularity was, by 2021, starting to expand at an exponential rate.

The pandemic had hit, meaning countless people in high income countries all around the world were stuck inside without work, many with cash from income-protection schemes like Australia's JobKeeper program.

This explosion of potential players came just as Stake's marketing tactics, boosted by Sarin's innovations, were coming into their own. The company expanded its reach further, sponsoring an English Premier League football club and the Ultimate Fighting Championship.

Among the masses of players flocking to the site was a name with serious star power. One day in 2021, Craven received a message from a Stake customer, who, as it turned out, was hanging out with Drake.

Before he knew it, Craven was on a video call with the Canadian pop star, who was standing on a basketball court inside his home.

Drake said he loved playing on the site. Craven said later that he'd thought he was being scammed. It was too absurd to be real. But once it became clear that it really was Drake, Craven sensed an opportunity.

Drake was announced as Stake's "brand ambassador" that same year.

Stake founders Ed Craven (left) and Bijan Tehrani (right) with the casino's ambassador and pop star Drake. ( )

The pop star appeared in viral marketing stunts and live-streamed himself making multi-million-dollar bets, projecting all the glamour of the high-rolling lifestyle onto a barely regulated casino.

As Chris struggled to control his gambling on Stake, he too was tapping into the rivers of money flowing in and out of the casino. He joined the casino's army of live-streaming influencers in late 2020.

He was never employed by Stake, and had no guaranteed income, however Craven offered financial support for Chris' efforts to entice others to play on Stake.

Eddie: Sup

Eddie: Hooked you up couple k in Bitcoin

Eddie: Hope you can get a decent run 🙂 Nice win on Monopoly on Twitter

Chris: Ty haha yeah a quite good win

Ed Craven shares a screenshot of a win he had on Stake. ( )

Eddie: I got this one yesterday

Eddie: 1000x haha

Eddie: Super addictive

Chris: What the i never hit those lmao

Chris: Most I think is like 100x

Chris: Gonna upload that sometime

Eddie: Ha nice, you still making vids? Nice

Make aure you attach ref links on all ya vids. Those things can pay for rest of ya life lol

When he live-streamed his gambling sessions, Chris says he would bet far more recklessly than usual.

He felt the pressure to put on a show and entertain those watching him. "I would lose [everything]," Chris says, "like within the first five to seven minutes."

Sean, who lives in Florida, used to watch Chris gamble live on Stake. "It was just an insane amount of money," he says. "[He would] be doing like six-figure blackjack hands."

Sean says he could see Chris had a gambling problem within a month of meeting him. "One time he lost 800 grand in what must have been a few minutes," he recalls. "And then after he lost it, he just instantly left the call."

Craven seemed aware of this tendency in Chris, even counselling him to bet in smaller increments so he could keep playing — and therefore promoting the casino — for longer.

Eddie: Just like 10 Euro max spins preferably bro

Eddie: And you be live stream whole time

Eddie: Idea is to make some long streaming content haha

Chris regularly sent Craven long lists of players to add to his affiliate list; not all of them would keep playing once their welcome bonus was gone, but those who did were putting money straight into Chris's pocket.

Chris's affiliate list grew quickly, he recalls, reaching about 300 players at its peak.

His cut of each deposit made by his affiliates was relatively small, but in aggregate it worked out to a serious income.

Other streamers found themselves with similar problems to Chris.

A Stake-affiliated influencer named Austin Michael Taylor, who called himself DNP3, caused a public scandal when he committed fraud to fund his gambling habit.

After running out of his own money to gamble with, Taylor took investor funds from a cryptocurrency project that he had launched in 2021, and used them to chase his losses. His sponsorship with Stake, he later wrote on social media, "unleashed an addiction [he] never knew [he] had."

Other similar scandals, involving a variety of online casinos, led to a crisis moment for Stake's promotional strategy.

Twitch — the world's most popular live-streaming platform, where most of Stake's promoters hung out — banned any content featuring what it called "unsafe" gambling sites.

The ban included Stake.

Months later, a new live-streaming platform called Kick emerged, with far more liberal policies.

It's CEO and part-owner: Ed Craven.

Several prominent gambling streamers quickly signed contracts with the new site, including Canadian streamer Felix Lengyel, known online as xQc, and American internet celebrity Adin Ross.

Felix Lengyel (centre) meets Donald Trump on a Kick live-stream. ( )

Lengyel's $US100-million contract with Kick included a clause requiring him to gamble on Stake while streaming, the streamer once said. Other streamers have made similar comments.

Still, Lengyel's relationship with gambling appears to be a complicated one. "I'm ill," he once said, referring to his addiction to gambling, "but you know what, I can afford to be ill."

By April 2023, Craven handed Chris off to another of Stake's VIP hosts.

The Stake CEO was a busy man. He was, by now, a certified billionaire, the owner of Australia's most expensive property, and the CEO of a major live-streaming platform.

Eddie: Hey bro

Eddie: If you reach out to @TejmanVIP he'll be able to renew the reload + send cashback etc & set all bonuses going forward. I've let him know to expect a message from you — He'll also have a nice extra bonus for when you reach out

Eddie: I'll still be here if you need anything unrelated to bonuses though, I'm not going anywhere :)

Chris: Yee I understand seen ur f1 stuff on Twitter some sick stuff

Eddie: hahah, yeh juggling a few things at once

Chris only reached out sporadically after that. When he did, Craven reminded him that he had a VIP host for these requests.

Their last exchange, in November 2024, followed the same pattern. Chris said he had lost $US700,000 on blackjack, and wanted a quarter of it back. "I went insane," he wrote to Craven.

Craven connected him with an on-duty VIP host, who would "be able to sort everything out".

And that's where they left things, until Chris filed a legal claim — via a lawyer — for $US1.5 million in lost winnings.

In the meantime, Chris had reached out to the Foundation for the Representation of Victims of Online Gaming, which assists players with claims against online casinos.

Roelof Bijkerk, an affiliate of the foundation based on the Dutch-Caribbean island of Curaçao, took on Chris's case against Stake.

Together, they prepared a demand letter — featuring the messaging history between Chris and Craven as its centrepiece — that claimed the casino "made gross misuse" of Chris's gambling addiction.

In response Stake argued that Chris was a "professional gambler" who was merely playing the "gambling addiction card" to recover his losses.

It said the company continuously monitors player patterns that might indicate gambling addiction and "there was no specific pattern in the timing of [Chris's] deposits that would indicate such a problem".

The casino also claims Chris actually made a profit while gambling there. He did hit the jackpot at times — he withdrew $US2.2 million from one account in November 2023 — though he is missing the gambling data from two of his Stake accounts, so the ABC could not determine his overall position.

If his claim were to be awarded, Stake's lawyers say, "it would go against the principle of fair play."

The only grounds for returning a player's losses, they argue, would be if its games had been rigged against them. "In gambling, the fundamental rule is: if you lose, you lose; if you win, you win."

In effect, they were saying that the casino's arsenal of psychological tactics — hosting games designed to "f*** player[s]" and undermining players' attempts to quit with bonuses and cool-off periods — were all fair game.

The case is ongoing.

As for his own complicity as a cog in Stake's promotional machine, Chris says he didn't think about it all that much at the time.

And now? "Yeah, a little bit," he says, and changes the subject.

Sometimes it's easier to look the other way.

Credits

title: Lyon 'absolutely filthy' as English star says shock dropping helped his rhythm
text:
Australia's controversial decision to drop Nathan Lyon is threatening to backfire as England's Zak Crawley has admitted he found it easier to find his rhythm facing an all-pace attack.

Lyon told Channel 7 he was "absolutely filthy" to have been axed for the second Ashes Test after also missing the last day-night Test on the tour of the West Indies in July.

It is just the second time since his 2011 debut that Lyon has missed a home Test, with the veteran spinner replaced by right-arm paceman Michael Neser.

But there were times Australia could have used Lyon on a seesawing first day of the pink-ball Test that ended with England going to stumps at 9-325 at the Gabba.

Australia are eight overs behind in their over rate, which could cost WTC points, after not playing spin at any point on Thursday.

There were times when Australia struggled for the breakthrough wickets that fell in clusters during their big win of the series opener.

With the condition of the ball apparently deteriorating, Jofra Archer and Joe Root toyed with the pacemen on a 61-run stand for the final wicket.

They will have the chance to continue batting in valuable daylight hours after the pacemen could not break the partnership under lights before stumps on Thursday.

Earlier, Zak Crawley (76) stretched out to his second-biggest score in Australia, before Root (135no) broke through for a first century in 30 innings Down Under.

Crawley admitted the tourists, under pressure for their poor batting in Perth, had been shocked not to have seen Lyon's name on the team sheet at the toss.

"I can't remember the last time other than in the West Indies recently that they haven't played him, so we were surprised," he said.

Other than big left-armer Starc, all of Australia's bowlers on Thursday were right-arm medium-pacers.

Neser, Cameron Green, Scott Boland and Brendan Doggett gave up 249 runs for only two wickets between them as Starc (6-71) inflicted the bulk of the damage.

Crawley conceded that the lack of variety made his job easier.

"I suppose there was some rhythm I could get in with the four seamers playing. It definitely got easier as the game wore on," he said.

"I don't know if that was the ball or picking up the rhythm of the pitch. After about 10 or 15 overs, it seemed to do a lot less."

Starc was not worried by the homogeneous pace of the attack.

"I'm not sure speed's the be-all and end-all. That's the makeup we've gone with this week," Starc said.

The left-armer said he did not feel extra pressure without Lyon, as the clearest source of variety in the attack.

"I didn't feel anything different, much like last week, just trying to play that role," Starc said.

Starc felt for Lyon, who learned of his omission only an hour before the toss on Thursday.

"It's a tough one for Nath. Everyone wants to play every game and I'm sure he'll be disappointed not to be playing this week," Starc said.

"The selectors certainly looked at the conditions and made the choice of that attack for these conditions. It's not a reflection of Nathan and his skills."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Housing crisis turns caravan park owners into 'landlords' of last resort
text:
Caravan park owners say they are copping the brunt of the housing crisis, as those on the brink of homelessness turn to these facilities as a last resort.

Owners have spoken to the ABC about the emotional toll of turning desperate people away and dealing with anti-social behaviour from some long-term residents.

Greg Homer has run the Waterloo Village Caravan Park on the outskirts of Bunbury, 160km south of Perth, with his family since 2011.

Greg Homer says turning away desperate people every day is taking a toll on him and his staff. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Mr Homer said, while he found running the park fulfilling, the demand for accommodation he faced on a daily basis was overwhelming.

"Our phone does not stop ringing every single day," he said.

"We've had people in tears at our front counter, people who come back multiple times a day."

Parks of last resort

Mr Homer's experience is indicative of the seismic shift in caravan park culture, brought on by an acute shortage of homes.

He said he was increasingly turning away locals pleading for any kind of accommodation.

Greg Homer wishes he had more room to help people find a place to live. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

"They'll be a family with a couple of small kids and asking if they just set up a tent anywhere on our property just to live, just to have something, so they are not sleeping in a car, so they can actually accommodate their kids," Mr Homer said.

"It's very, very tough to face that."

Mr Homer said he understood why caravan parks were such a popular choice for people struggling financially.

"We tend to be the most affordable of all styles of accommodation … so we've seen more and more people who are interested," he said.

"I don't think I've had a vacancy at the caravan park now for probably four to five months."

Greg Homer says the number of people being turned away is sometimes emotionally overwhelming. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Kylie Holt has been living in a converted 1967 Leyland Leopard school bus for five years with her young family on long-term sites in the South West.

"We're all reliant on having somewhere to call home, no matter how humble that becomes, and just trying to provide that stability for yourself and your family," Mrs Holt said.

Kylie Holt says she is not confident she would find another caravan park with vacancies if she was forced to start looking now. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

She said she had seen a significant increase in the number of people using caravan parks as long-term accommodation.

"I'd say where we are, the amount of permanent families and people that we had doubled in the last three years," she said.

"From young mums with children, older men who have come out of divorce or widowed, and they can't afford a mortgage on their pension — a lot of different scenarios."

Tourism operator to landlord

The South West experienced a 62.9 per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness between 2016 and 2021, which was the second largest increase in the state, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

South West caravan park manager Angela Kaitsioukas said she struggled with the shift from short-term holiday makers to long-term accommodation.

Waterloo Village Caravan Park offers alternative types of long-term accommodation for people who do not have a caravan of their own. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Ms Kaitsioukas said anti-social behaviour was causing safety concerns for her staff.

"There have been a couple of times where I have been quite scared to the point that now we actually have a pepper spray in our top drawer in the office," she said.

"We need everyone [customers] to have a current police clearance, no older than, like, six months old.

"We had been actually given a lot of false police clearances … I didn't realise that people would actually go to that length."

Angela Kaitsioukas says more anti-social behaviour is making work challenging. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Ms Kaitsioukas said she was considering removing long-term residency as an option because of the stress.

"I'm not sure that we will continue on doing it just because each year it seems to be getting a lot worse," she said.

" We do want to be, ultimately, just a caravan park. "

'An emergency valve'

Anglicare CEO Mark Glasson said even caravan park space had been exhausted by the prolonged housing shortage.

"The inaccessibility of caravan parks for many people means that they are sleeping rough, they're sleeping in their cars, in tents, in people's backyards," he said.

"There's also a worrying trend that what was once an emergency valve is no longer available."

title: Will Oscar play kingmaker? Piastri ducks big F1 title question
text:
Oscar Piastri has sidestepped the question of whether he'd be prepared to play Formula One kingmaker by helping teammate and overwhelming championship favourite Lando Norris race to the world drivers' crown.

Norris, who leads by 12 points from champion Max Verstappen and 16 from McLaren teammate Piastri going into the season-ending Abu Dhabi Grand Prix with all three still in the hunt, said on Thursday he felt he would help the Australian if the boot was on the other foot.

But quizzed on his stance, Piastri neatly ducked the burning topic on pre-race media day, shrugging: "It's not something we've discussed — I don't really have an answer until I know what's expected of me."

Others, though, had plenty to say, with Mercedes driver George Russell adamant it would be "unfair" to ask Piastri to sacrifice his admittedly slim title chances, even if it meant neither McLaren driver ended up being champion.

His advice to Piastri? Unplug his car radio.

"I don't think it's acceptable or reasonable to ask a driver who's also in a shot at a championship in the very last race to move over for your teammate," Russell said.

"They both need to be given a shot, and if they lose out because of it, you just need to say the other guy did a better job and that's racing."

How Oscar Piastri can still win the F1 world title Oscar Piastri's hopes of winning the F1 title suffered a hammer blow after McLaren's strategy error in Qatar, but there is still hope. Here's how the Aussie can upset the odds in Abu Dhabi's decider.

Norris, for his part, said he wouldn't ask Piastri for any help in a potential scenario where, say, he was fourth in the race with Verstappen leading and Piastri third — a situation which would result in the Red Bull champ retaining his crown unless the McLaren drivers switched positions.

Quizzed over whether he would ask Piastri to sacrifice a place to help him, Norris, sounding a mite uncomfortable as his two title rivals sat alongside, said: "I don't think I would ask it because … I don't know … it's up to Oscar if he would allow it. I don't think it's necessarily down to me.

"It's the same, if it's the other way around. Would I be willing to or not? Personally, I think I would just, because I feel like I'm always like that and that's just how I am.

"I'm not going to ask it, I don't want to ask it because I don't think it's necessarily a fair question," he added.

"At the same time, if that's how it ends and Max wins, then, well, that's it. Congrats to him, and look forward to next year. It doesn't change anything. It doesn't change my life. He will deserve it over us."

It seems unthinkable, though, that McLaren wouldn't ask Piastri to play the perfect team man again — a role he's played selflessly before in the British outfit — if it looked as if the team might miss out on the drivers' title after such a dominant year.

Principal Andrea Stella, after all, had said after last Sunday's Qatar Grand Prix, where a strategy bungle ruined both their chances, that "what's important for us is that we are in condition to beat Verstappen with one of our two drivers".

He also said then that, though the team's racing approach would not change, there would be conversations this week — yet both drivers reckoned there had been none so far.

Norris admitted he felt he had most to lose of the three contenders — and Piastri seemed more relaxed as he explained how he's feeling "a lot of confidence" off the back of his superb weekend in Qatar.

"Obviously, I need a fair few things to happen this weekend to come out champion, but I'll just make sure I'm in the right place at the right time and see what happens," he said.

"Obviously, it would be a very cool achievement, but I'm not getting my hopes up too high. We'll see what happens. If I can achieve it, then I'd be a pretty happy guy."

AAP

title: Compressed air energy storage is coming, but how does it work?
text:
Broken Hill's hard-rock geology could hold part of the solution to Australia's energy storage problem as the country shifts to renewables.

A 200-megawatt, $1 billion facility built by Canadian company Hydrostor near the historic mining city will be Australia's first large-scale compressed air energy storage facility, capable of powering up to 80,000 homes for a day.

The Silver City Energy Storage Centre will be able to store energy for about eight hours, longer than lithium-ion batteries, which typically hold about four hours of charge in large grid-scale batteries.

That means solar energy generated during the day can be soaked up and then released through the night.

Abundant daytime renewable energy is wasted because of a lack of storage, and this figure is growing as more renewables come online.

It is estimated Australia will need up to 20 times more energy storage by 2050, and simply adding more lithium-ion batteries is not the solution because of their high cost and the limit on the number of hours they efficiently store energy.

What is compressed air energy storage?

A compressed-air energy storage facility is a bit like a pneumatic nail gun but on a much bigger scale, says Ben Clennell, a research scientist at the CSIRO, who has done work for Hydrostor in the past.

During periods of high supply, renewable energy is used to pump atmospheric air, under pressure, into a storage container. It is then released during periods of high demand to drive a turbine and generate electricity.

An impression of the Hydrostor site. (Supplied: NSW government)

"It's a bit like storing air in a compressed air cylinder," Dr Clennell says.

Unlike a nail gun, the Broken Hill facility has several extra steps to improve efficiency.

The process of compressing the air generates heat. Your reverse-cycle heater works on the same principle. This surplus heat is stored and then used to heat the stored air when it is decompressed.

The Broken Hill facility also uses water for a process called "hydrostatic compensation".

The compressed air is stored in a water-filled 280,000 cubic-metre underground cavern, 600 metres below the surface.

"As the air goes into the underground cavern, it pushes water out of the cavern to a lake at the top," Dr Clennell said.

A diagram showing how Hydrostor's Compressed Air Energy Storage System works. (Supplied: Hydrostor)

To tap this stored energy, the process is reversed — water is allowed to flow from the surface reservoir back into the underground cavern, pushing air back to the surface where it's reheated and used to spin turbines that generate electricity.

Hydrostor, the Canadian company behind the Silver City Energy Storage Centre, said it would use a disused underground mine site adjacent to the proposed cavern to access and excavate rock to create the cavern.

"It [the rock] will hold water and air without having to line it or build a steel vessel because it's very high-density rock," said Martin Becker, from Hydrostor.

Dr Clennell said big compressed-air energy storage facilities had to be underground.

"You can store air in pressure vessels or pipes, or various other arrangements at the surface, but they would rapidly become very large if you're wanting to store hundreds of megawatt hours of electricity-equivalent power," he said.

Why use hydrostatic compensation?

Adding water makes the process more complicated, but more efficient, robust and reliable, according to Seamus Garvey, a professor of energy dynamics at the University of Nottingham.

Professor Seamus Garvey recently established the Medium Duration Energy Storage Alliance. (Supplied: Seamus Garvey)

It means that when energy is needed, all of the air pumped into the underground cavern can be released through the turbines. Without water, some of the air would need to be left in the cavern to avoid creating a partial vacuum.

"You can get all the air back out of the tank when you want to empty it," Professor Garvey said.

The compressor and turbines can work at the same optimal pressure, which makes them more efficient.

Water also mitigates damage to the storage vessels due to stress on materials caused by cycles of pressurisation and depressurisation — similar to the way the repeated heating and cooling of the ground during the day and night causes rock to warp and then crack.

"[The materials are in] big tension when the tank is full of high-pressure air, and then they relax a little bit when it's not full of high-pressure air," Professor Garvey said.

How efficient is a compressed air energy storage system?

Hydrostor said the Broken Hill facility would have a round-trip efficiency of about 66 per cent.

This meant about two-thirds of the electricity used to power the air compressors was later recovered as electricity generated by the turbines.

Hydrostor said it would take 12 hours to charge the system, which stored energy for eight hours.

CSIRO's Dr Ben Clennell says compressed air energy is ideal for long-term energy storage. (Supplied: CSIRO)

Mr Martin said the system was more efficient than traditional compressed air storage because it captured heat and stored it in tanks on the surface.

"You can't run cool air through these turbines [to generate electricity]. The air needs to be at a certain operating range and temperature," he said.

"In traditional compressed air, when the air is reused to generate, they normally use natural gas. That is very inefficient because you're … introducing a fossil fuel source.

"So by capturing that heat, storing it and re-injecting it, you're eliminating the need to introduce another fuel."

Even so, Dr Clennell said some energy would be lost as heat.

"In heat transfer processes, there will be some losses," he said.

"Then as the air expands, there will be some friction, and you generate more heat that wouldn't all be recovered, and so on.

"So you have losses in the machinery and in the tubing and in the heat exchangers."

Compressed air systems were not as efficient as pumped hydro energy storage, said Graham Nathan, research director at the Heavy Industry Low-carbon Transition Cooperative Research Centre (HILT CRC).

"I mean 66 per cent [efficiency] is pretty good, but it's still pretty lossy. You'd like to be able to get 95 per cent, but of course you never would," he said.

Why compressed air energy storage?

Despite being less efficient than other forms of energy storage, compressed air energy storage has some major advantages.

Large amounts of air can be stored relatively cheaply, Professor Nathan said.

"Batteries would be more efficient, but they'd be a much higher cost, and you wouldn't be able to get stuff of that size without being much, much more expensive," he said.

Professor Graham Nathan says compressed air energy storage is a cheap way to store large amounts of energy. (Supplied: HILT CRC)

Professor Garvey said compressed air could also store energy for longer than lithium-ion batteries.

"Batteries tend to be excellent solutions for energy storage that will discharge for relatively short periods of time, like up to four hours," he said.

"[But] most of the action that happens with energy storage … happens in a medium-sized set of time."

Four hours of energy storage is useful for delivering stored solar to households in the evening, after the sun has set, but not so helpful for meeting demand through the night and the following morning.

Energy storage of 4 to 12 hours is known as "medium duration".

Technologies in this area include storing energy as heat in thermal blocks, or as potential energy as weights suspended from cranes, or new kinds of battery technologies currently undergoing testing such as vanadium redox-flow batteries.

Professor Garvey recently set up a Medium Duration Energy Storage Alliance to help provide recognition that medium duration storage is distinct from short and long duration energy storage.

How much medium storage energy storage does Australia need?

Australia needs 10-20 times more energy storage of all kinds by 2050 to meet its net zero emissions target, according to the CSIRO.

By 2030, about a quarter of energy storage should be medium duration, according to the Australian Energy Market Operator, which also forecasts strong demand.

New South Wales has legislated a 2-gigawatt target for storage of at least eight hours duration by 2030.

It is less than halfway towards its target.

"We do see it as a very important element of energy storage technology in the future," Dr Clennell said.

title: Australian-backed bid gathers pace to restart Tahmoor mine
text:
A local consortium says it is "hastily" working on a bid to take over the mothballed Tahmoor mine, owned by British billionaire Sanjeev Gupta, to ensure operations start soon and "there is a workforce to come back".

The Tahmoor coking coal mine, south-west of Sydney, has been closed since February after running out of cash amid financial turmoil within Mr Gupta's GFG Alliance.

About 500 workers, including contractors, were stood down on minimum pay, and in November, about half were told they would not be paid.

William Buck was appointed administrator of Liberty Primary Metals Australia (LPMA) in November.

LPMA is the holding entity for GFG's Australian steel and mining businesses, including Tahmoor, and relies heavily on income from the mine to meet its financial obligations.

About 500 workers were stood down when operations ceased at the Tahmoor mine earlier this year. (ABC News: Shaun Kingma)
